catalyst.source: The novel composite photocatalyst of trimodal porous silica (TPS)/g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes was fabricated via a twostep hydrothermal synthesis method with intermediate pretreatment.
catalyst.context: The novel composite photocatalyst of trimodal porous silica (TPS)/g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes was fabricated via a twostep hydrothermal synthesis method with intermediate pretreatment.The TPS was extracted from rice husk, which is agricultural waste, to further reduce the cost of photocatalyst preparation.A series of characterization results, including X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, N 2 adsorption-desorption, and pore size analysis, illustrated the properties of crystal, pore structure, and morphology of the composite photocatalyst.The TPS/g-C 3 N 4 presented a hollow tubular shape with a large surface area and CO 2 adsorption capacity, so there were more catalytic active reaction sites.The photocatalytic activity measurement was operated, and only ethanol was detected when g-C 3 N 4 NT and composite TGNT were used as photocatalysts.In particular, the ethanol yield of TGNT2 was 196 m/g, and after 10 cycles of running, the photocatalytic activity decreased by less than 5.UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra, photoluminescence spectra, and photoelectrochemical analysis revealed the mechanism of the photocatalytic activity enhancement from the aspects of visible light absorption, photo-generated electronhole pair separation and transfer, and charges recombination.It theoretically explained the prospect of this fabrication strategy.It demonstrated that TGNT is a low-cost, stable, efficient, and promising photocatalyst to reduce CO 2 to ethanol under visible light.

catalyst.context: Melamine, Polyethylene glycol (PEG) 400, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), ammonia aqueous, NaOH, KHCO 3 , and Na 2 SO 3 were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent.All reagents used in this work were analytically pure and used without further purification.Sodium silicate solution was extracted from rice husk by the alkali solution method.Briefly, 38 g of calcined rice husk ash and 10 g of NaOH were mixed in 350 mL of water, and then stirred and refluxed at 70 C for 24 h.The mixed liquid was filtered, and the Si content in the clear liquid measured by ICP-OES was 39.1 g/L. The g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (NT) were prepared by a two-step process with a hydrothermal performing process.Firstly, 2 g of melamine was dissolved into 120 mL of deionized water under the condition of stirring at 80 C for 10 min.Then, the obtained clear solution was transferred to a 200 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 180 C for 24 h.The crystalline product, preformed white melamine-cyanuric acid (MCA), was collected by filtered, washed several times with water, and completely dried.Secondly, the 3 g of MCA precursor was placed in an alumina crucible with a cover and then calcined at 550 C for h in a tube furnace with N 2 gas flow.For comparison, the bulk g-C 3 N 4 was prepared by thermal polymerization of melamine.Typically, 2 g of melamine was heated at 550 C for 4 h.The light yellow powder was collected after cooled and ground. The TPS was synthesized by the following soft template method.10 g of PEG was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water and stirred for min at 40 C, which labeled as solution A. 1 g of CTAB was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water at 60 C, which labeled as solution B. Solution A was added to solution B, and then 18 mL of sodium silicate solution was added dropwise to the mixed solution after 1 mL of ammonia aqueous was added.The mixture gel was stirred with 300 r/min at 40 C for 8 h.Finally, the product was filtrated, washed, and dried.Then the template was removed by heated to 550 C for 6 h with a ramp rate of 10 C/min. The TPS/g-C 3 N 4 NT composite was prepared by a hydrothermal method.0.3 g of g-C 3 N 4 NT was dispersed in 100 mL of water by ultrasonic treatment for 10 min.0.1 g of TPS was added to the above suspension, and the ultrasonic treatment was continued for 30 min.Then, the mixed solution was transferred to a 200 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 120 C for 12 h.Finally, the product was filtrated, washed with deionized water, and dried at 80 C. Samples with the same preparation method but different amounts of TPS, 0.1 g, 0.2 g, and 0.3 g, were labeled TGNT1, TGNT2, and TGNT3. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) with Cu K radiation ( 0.154 nm).The pattern data was recorded at 2 5 to 75 with the step size of 0.02 .Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed on a Cary 660 Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer (Agilent Technologies, Australia) in the range of 4000-600 cm -1 .X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data was obtained using an Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer (KRATOS, UK) using monochromatic Al K radiation (h1486.6eV).The signal at 284.8 eV of the C (1s) region was employed to adjust the binding energies for all of the XPS spectra.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on an ULTRA PLUS field emission scanning electron microscope (ZEISS, Germany) at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were observed with a JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope (JEOL, Japan) working at 200 kV.The N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherm at -196 C and CO 2 adsorption isotherm at 0 C were measured on an ASAP 2460 static adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics, USA).Specific surface area, pore size distribution, and total pore volume were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method, the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) method, and the adsorption amount at the relative pressure P/P 0 of 0.995.Before each measurement, the samples were degassed at 200 C for 6 h.UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) data was conducted using a Lambda 650S UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Perkin-Elmer, USA) in the wavelength range of 200-800 nm.Photoluminescence (PL) spectra was recorded using a Fluoromax-4 spectrophotometer (HORIBA, Japan) with an excitation wavelength of 325 nm. Photocatalytic activity measurement was carried out in a homemade closed photocatalytic reactor.It can control the gas flow through a mass flow controller (AALBORG, USA), cut off the gas path through the valves, and control the reaction temperature through a chiller (YKKY, China).The experiment of stable photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 under visible light irradiation is thus realized.Before illumination, 100 mg of photocatalysts were suspended in 100 mL of KHCO 3 (0.1 M) and Na 2 SO 3 (0.1 M) under magnetic stirring in the double-layer Pyrex glass reactor, and pure CO 2 gas was continuously through the solution for 30 min to eliminate air and dissolve oxygen.KHCO 3 is used to solution to enhance the solubility of CO 2 during photocatalytic reactions, and Na 2 SO 3 act as holes sacrifice agent 36.A 300 W Xe lamp (Microsolar300, PerfectLight, China) equipped with a cutoff filter ( 420 nm) was used as the visible light source to illuminate the reactant through the quartz window.A constant temperature water tank filled with ethylene glycol aqueous solution was used to control the reaction temperature at 0 C.During the entire irradiation process, pure CO 2 was continuously bubbled through the above solution in the reactor.At a certain time interval, a syringe with a nylon membrane filter (pore size 0.45 m) was used to take out 0.5 mL of liquid product to remove the photocatalyst particles.The ethanol concentration of the 3.0 L liquid sample was analyzed by a QP2010 Ultra gas chromatography mass spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan) with an AOC-20i auto-injector.The gas in the headspace of the reactor was analyzed by a 6890N gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies, USA).Under the same experimental conditions, the comparative experiment was carried out in the dark or without CO 2 gas flow.After the reaction, the sample was separated by centrifugation for repeated measurements, which was to investigate the recyclability.The 13 C isotope labeling experiment was performed to verify that the products were from CO 2 photocatalytic conversion.The 13 CO 2 was used as feed gas instead of 12 CO 2 in the reaction process, and the products were analyzed by the QP2010 Ultra GC-MS. 5 mg of the photocatalyst was dispersed in a mixed solution of 1 mL of water, 0.35 mL of ethanol, and 10 L of nafion.150 L of the sample was dropped on indium tin oxide (ITO) glass with the area of 1 0.8 cm 2 and dried in a vacuum.The photocurrent measurement was carried out on a CHI660E electrochemical analyzer (ChenHua, China).It was operated in a three-electrode system, and a platinum electrode, indium tin oxide glass, and saturated Ag/AgCl electrode were acted as the counter electrode, working electrode, and standard electrode, respectively.The electrolyte was a 0.1 M sodium sulfate solution.Electrochemical impendence spectroscopes (EIS) was carried out on a PP211 electrochemical analyzer (Zahner, Germany).It was performed in the presence of 5 mM K 3 Fe(CN) 6 /K 4 Fe(CN) 6 (1:1) mixture as a redox probe in 0.1 M potassium chloride (KCl) at 0.24 V.

(1).In order for the catalytic process to occur, the charges need respectively migrate to the reaction sites on the photocatalyst surface and avoid recombination.There, electrons and holes respectively reduce the adsorbed electron acceptor CO 2 molecules and oxidize the electron donor H 2 O, which is described in Eqs. ( 2) and (3).The production of CH 3 OH and C 2 H 5 OH through the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 is shown in Eqs. ( 4) and (5).Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction is a complex path for multi-electron transfer, and multiple products are obtained.From the thermodynamic perspective, six electrons or twelve electrons are required to convert one CO 2 molecule to form CH 3 OH or C 2 H 5 OH.The hollow tubular structure can not only provide effective light collection ability due to multiple light reflections or scattering in the internal space, but also can reduce the diffusion distance from the inside to the surface, thereby accelerating the separation of charge carriers 70.Therefore, TGNT can undertake the conversion process of ethanol with more charge transfer, while bulk g-C 3 N 4 can only produce methanol and a small amount of ethanol. not have the photocatalytic reduction activity of CO 2 .After 8 h of photocatalytic reaction, the ethanol yield of the prepared photocatalyst tends to be stable.The gas in the headspace of the reactor ethanol output is 113 mol/g.Then, the activity of composite TGNT loaded with TPS is further enhanced, and TGNT2 reached 196 mol/g.However, the ethanol yield of TGNT3 is improved less, which is due to characterized by XRD and FTIR after 10 cycles of running in Fig. S8.From the crystal plane diffraction peak and chemical bond absorption peak, it can be seen that its crystal structure and chemical structure have not changed.It indicates that this composite photocatalyst can be stably used repeatedly for a long time.The comparison of various recently reported g-C 3 N 4 based photocatalysts previously with the present work for the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction was listed in Table S2.It can be seen that the present work has prepared a composite photocatalyst with considerable catalytic activity by a universal and simple hydrothermal method. High-sensitivity steady-state PL spectra of as-prepared photocatalysts are shown in Fig. 8(a).The emission peak of g-C 3 N 4 is displayed at 475 nm, but due to the quantum confinement effect caused by the TGNT composite structure, the emission peak shifts to 450 nm 73.The PL emission peak intensity of g-C 3 N 4 NT is significantly lower than that of bulk g-C 3 N 4 , and TGNT1 and TGNT2 are further lower.The low emission peak intensity indicates that the recombination rate of charge carriers is much lower, and the charge transfer in TGNT1 and TGNT2 is faster 74.The emission peak intensity of TGNT3 is extremely enhanced, indicating that loading a large amount of TPS will result in faster recombination of charge carriers.Although TGNT3 has better light absorption performance and larger surface area, the rapid recombination of carriers limits the photocatalytic reduction process and therefore leads to the lowest catalytic activity.As shown in Fig. 8(b), the transient photocurrent response analyses were performed under a visible light lamp that turns on and off repeatedly to investigate the charge separation and transfer efficiency.The photocurrent response quickly after light on, and the current density of all photocatalysts can be ignored during light off.The rapid response of current to light irradiation indicates that the charge is quickly transferred in the photocatalyst 75.The corresponding reproducibility of the photocurrent is stable in several cycles of light irradiation, which leads to stable catalytic performance after multiple irradiations and repeated use.The photocurrent intensity of TGNT2 is twice that of g-C 3 N 4 NT, indicating that loading TPS greatly improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs 76,77.In order to further confirm the improvement of charge separation and transfer efficiency, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of g-C 3 N 4 NT and TGNT2 were investigated, as shown in the Fig. 8(c).The Nyquist plot shows that the arc radius of TGNT2 is smaller than that of g-C 3 N 4 , which is attributed to the fact that the TPS composite material reduces the charge transfer resistance and increases the electronic conductivity.It results in more effective charge separation, and the excellent charge transfer capability is consistent with the above photocurrent response 78,79.As shown in Fig. 8(d), the structure of the nanotube and the load of the TPS affect the expansion of the band gap.The increase in the band gap of the TGNT can be attributed to the O defect effect due to the loading of silica 80.Photoelectrons and holes can be constrained at the defect site, and new intrinsic or extrinsic absorption bands can be generated in the band gap of SiO 2 , which optimizes the redox couple chosen as photocatalysis/photoelectrochemical applications 81.These factors lead to changes in the energy band structure, and a suitable energy band structure can thermodynamically realize the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction.

light source.context: The novel composite photocatalyst of trimodal porous silica (TPS)/g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes was fabricated via a twostep hydrothermal synthesis method with intermediate pretreatment.The TPS was extracted from rice husk, which is agricultural waste, to further reduce the cost of photocatalyst preparation.A series of characterization results, including X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, N 2 adsorption-desorption, and pore size analysis, illustrated the properties of crystal, pore structure, and morphology of the composite photocatalyst.The TPS/g-C 3 N 4 presented a hollow tubular shape with a large surface area and CO 2 adsorption capacity, so there were more catalytic active reaction sites.The photocatalytic activity measurement was operated, and only ethanol was detected when g-C 3 N 4 NT and composite TGNT were used as photocatalysts.In particular, the ethanol yield of TGNT2 was 196 m/g, and after 10 cycles of running, the photocatalytic activity decreased by less than 5.UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra, photoluminescence spectra, and photoelectrochemical analysis revealed the mechanism of the photocatalytic activity enhancement from the aspects of visible light absorption, photo-generated electronhole pair separation and transfer, and charges recombination.It theoretically explained the prospect of this fabrication strategy.It demonstrated that TGNT is a low-cost, stable, efficient, and promising photocatalyst to reduce CO 2 to ethanol under visible light.

light source.context: Melamine, Polyethylene glycol (PEG) 400, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), ammonia aqueous, NaOH, KHCO 3 , and Na 2 SO 3 were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent.All reagents used in this work were analytically pure and used without further purification.Sodium silicate solution was extracted from rice husk by the alkali solution method.Briefly, 38 g of calcined rice husk ash and 10 g of NaOH were mixed in 350 mL of water, and then stirred and refluxed at 70 C for 24 h.The mixed liquid was filtered, and the Si content in the clear liquid measured by ICP-OES was 39.1 g/L. The g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (NT) were prepared by a two-step process with a hydrothermal performing process.Firstly, 2 g of melamine was dissolved into 120 mL of deionized water under the condition of stirring at 80 C for 10 min.Then, the obtained clear solution was transferred to a 200 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 180 C for 24 h.The crystalline product, preformed white melamine-cyanuric acid (MCA), was collected by filtered, washed several times with water, and completely dried.Secondly, the 3 g of MCA precursor was placed in an alumina crucible with a cover and then calcined at 550 C for h in a tube furnace with N 2 gas flow.For comparison, the bulk g-C 3 N 4 was prepared by thermal polymerization of melamine.Typically, 2 g of melamine was heated at 550 C for 4 h.The light yellow powder was collected after cooled and ground. The TPS was synthesized by the following soft template method.10 g of PEG was dissolved in 40 mL deionized water and stirred for min at 40 C, which labeled as solution A. 1 g of CTAB was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water at 60 C, which labeled as solution B. Solution A was added to solution B, and then 18 mL of sodium silicate solution was added dropwise to the mixed solution after 1 mL of ammonia aqueous was added.The mixture gel was stirred with 300 r/min at 40 C for 8 h.Finally, the product was filtrated, washed, and dried.Then the template was removed by heated to 550 C for 6 h with a ramp rate of 10 C/min. The TPS/g-C 3 N 4 NT composite was prepared by a hydrothermal method.0.3 g of g-C 3 N 4 NT was dispersed in 100 mL of water by ultrasonic treatment for 10 min.0.1 g of TPS was added to the above suspension, and the ultrasonic treatment was continued for 30 min.Then, the mixed solution was transferred to a 200 mL PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 120 C for 12 h.Finally, the product was filtrated, washed with deionized water, and dried at 80 C. Samples with the same preparation method but different amounts of TPS, 0.1 g, 0.2 g, and 0.3 g, were labeled TGNT1, TGNT2, and TGNT3. the valves, and control the reaction temperature through a chiller (YKKY, China).The experiment of stable photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 under visible light irradiation is thus realized.Before illumination, 100 mg of photocatalysts were suspended in 100 mL of KHCO 3 (0.1 M) and Na 2 SO 3 (0.1 M) under magnetic stirring in the double-layer Pyrex glass reactor, and pure CO 2 gas was continuously through the solution for 30 min to eliminate air and dissolve oxygen.KHCO 3 is used to solution to enhance the solubility of CO 2 during photocatalytic reactions, and Na 2 SO 3 act as window.A constant temperature water tank filled with ethylene glycol aqueous solution was used to control the reaction temperature at 0 C.During the entire irradiation process, pure CO 2 was continuously bubbled through the above solution in the reactor.At a certain time interval, a syringe with a nylon membrane filter (pore size 0.45 m) was used to take out 0.5 mL of liquid product to remove the photocatalyst particles.The ethanol concentration of the 3.0 L liquid sample was analyzed by a QP2010 Ultra gas chromatography mass spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan) with an AOC-20i auto-injector.The gas in the headspace of the reactor was analyzed by a 6890N gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies, USA).Under the same experimental conditions, the comparative experiment was carried out in the dark or without CO 2 gas flow.After the reaction, the sample was separated by centrifugation for repeated measurements, which was to investigate the recyclability.The 13 C isotope labeling experiment was performed to verify that the products were from CO 2 photocatalytic conversion.The 13 CO 2 was used as feed gas instead of 12 CO 2 in the reaction process, and the products were analyzed by the QP2010 Ultra GC-MS. 5 mg of the photocatalyst was dispersed in a mixed solution of 1 mL of water, 0.35 mL of ethanol, and 10 L of nafion.150 L of the sample was dropped on indium tin oxide (ITO) glass with the area of 1 0.8 cm 2 and dried in a vacuum.The photocurrent measurement was carried out on a CHI660E electrochemical analyzer (ChenHua, China).It was operated in a three-electrode system, and a platinum electrode, indium tin oxide glass, and saturated Ag/AgCl electrode were acted as the counter electrode, working electrode, and standard electrode, respectively.The electrolyte was a 0.1 M sodium sulfate solution.Electrochemical impendence spectroscopes (EIS) was carried out on a PP211 electrochemical analyzer (Zahner, Germany).It was performed in the presence of 5 mM K 3 Fe(CN) 6 /K 4 Fe(CN) 6 (1:1) mixture as a redox probe in 0.1 M potassium chloride (KCl) at 0.24 V.
